manufacturerProductDescription.media_text: Free Lunch Punching Bag Road Home Abuela, Don't Forget Me More Moving True Stories from Rex Ogle Rex navigates his first semester of sixth grade as a poor kid in a wealthy school district. His story of hunger and hardship threaded with hope illuminates the lived experience of poverty in America. The compelling true story of a high school career defined by outbursts of domestic violence at home. Moments of grace and humor act as beacons of light in Rex’s dark struggle against the cycle of violence. The summer before he graduates high school, Rex is kicked out his home for being gay, and he ends up on the streets. His reflection on his hunger—for food, for love, and for a home—completes his trilogy of moving memoirs. Throughout a childhood marked by violence, Abuela’s red-brick house offered Rex the possibility of home. In this poetry collection, Rex honors Abuela’s legacy as a pillar of comfort, safety, and love.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 21, 2024
reviews.reviewText: As a kid who grew up with free lunch, abuse at home, and friends who had 'everything', I didn't feel like I was anyone until I grew up. I was the bookworm, the nerd, etc. This book resonated with me because of my experiences. I wish that more teachers would use this book as a teaching moment. I loved it.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great book for the family
reviews.reviewText: They teach a lot at school but there is no class on compassion. I would recommend reading this with your older kids so you can have some positive discussions and grow some capacity to care about others

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Phenomenal. Should be required reading.
reviews.reviewText: This book is heart wrenching, beautifully written, and deeply important. Should be required reading in schools. Whiles it’s a very easy reading level for adults, strongly recommend for adults as well.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 11, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Difficult to be inside this world
reviews.reviewText: I wish I had known from the start that this was a work of non-fiction. I really wanted justice for Rex. I’m glad his mom got work and things were looking up but the extreme abuse seemed to go unchecked and it was very hard to hear all of what happened. The writing was decent but the story tore me up.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I loved the reality of the story. I, too, lived a life where no one knew what went on behind closed doors.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 23, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Great book to read. I had my child who is in middle school read this book. It helped inform him about how things are for others. It also generated questions and discussions that might have not come up if the content was not presented. Definitely recommend purchasing for anyone. This book helps make people aware of others perspectives/experiences.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2021
reviews.reviewText: I had to read this book over the past week for my sophomore year honors literature class at BGSU. This book was heartbreaking, as it tells the story of Rex Ogle’s sixth grade year that was full of abuse, neglect, and too many horrifying events that a child should not have to experience. The memoir touches on many topics that are hard for some to discuss, but are still very important to talk about. After reading this book, my class had the honor of meeting Rex Ogle, the author, and learning more about him, while getting the chance to ask questions about him and his writings! He is an awesome guy, and his story is one that should be shared to all who want to hear it— it truly allows the reader to put into perspective their own life, while picking up on life lessons through every page. (I also rated this book moderate for the “difficulty” level because while its an easy ready vocabulary wise, it does take mental strength to read about the things that Rex had to go through— especially if the reader had experienced things similar)

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 13, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars awesome book heartbreaking at times
reviews.reviewText: Great book Awful for Rex that he endured so much but persevered . Read this with your kids touches on many subjects

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 9, 2020
reviews.reviewText: An easy read and an insight into how children have to deal with image and mental health issues in the home.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 13, 2019
reviews.reviewTitle: Loved this true life story even though at times it was heart wrenching to read.
reviews.reviewText: Wonderful but heart-wrenching tale. So well written. Highly recommend.
